Indeed, we do not use automatic mocking frameworks for JUnit's self-tests.
=
 In many places, we test features by what you might consider
integration-st=
yle, constructing test classes that use the feature, and
asserting the desi=
red outcomes.  In some others, we use hand-rolled mocks.

Let me know if yo=
u have any questions about translating particular idioms.

   David Saff

O=
n Tue, Feb 12, 2013 at 2:46 PM, Noel Yap <noel.yap@...> wrote:

> **
=
>
>
> I have created better support for filters (primarily
> CategoriesIncl=
udeFilter and CategoriesExcludeFilter but any Filter can
> be plugged in, i=
ncluding an IgnoreFilter that uses the filter
> mechanism to support @Ignor=
e). I would like to contribute this code to
> the JUnit project but it uses=
 mocks for some of the testing. What
> mocking framework does the JUnit pro=
ject use in its testing? If it
> currently doesn't use a mocking framework,=
 should I rewrite the tests
> to be more end-to-end?
>
> Thanks,
> Noel
